pullRequest.title: [#1976] Move hot state management into store
pullRequest.bodyText:
PR Description
As a preliminary step in addressing #1976, move hot state management into the Store.  This consolidates hot state management in one place:  previously hot states were kept in both the Database and the Store.  This change also necessitated moving pruning logic from the Database into the Store.
Additionally, all knowably non-canonical blocks are now pruned whenever we finalized a new checkpoint.  This includes blocks that do not descend from the latest finalized block and blocks that descend from the latest finalized block, but are at or prior to latest finalized epoch boundary.   For example, if block 30 finalizes epoch 1 (with epoch boundary at slot 32), other blocks at slots 30, 31, or 32 will be pruned as invalid.
As a result of these changes, a fair number of tests needed to be updated to operate on valid chain data.

commit.message: Rework Database state api - only return finalized states

Move hotState managment and pruning logic into RecentChainData

Make pruning more robust - prune all knowably non-canonical blocks

nodes.bodyText: Hmm - I think the current structure is problematic.  We do these calculations upfront to figure out our updates, send those updates to storage, and only then get a writeLock to actually update our in-memory Store.  But with that setup, we could interleave multiple transactions and commit the calculated changes out of order, and run into problems while trying to calculate the updates because the Store can change out from under us ...

commit.message: Throw an exception if StateGenerator fails to regenerate any state

Add latest finalized state tracking back in

We can't substitute latest finalized state for the checkpoint state: the
checkpoint state does not necessarily correspond to the latest finalized
block's state.  If the finalized block is prior to the epoch boundary
slot, its corresponding checkpoint state will be advanced to the epoch
boundary slot.
Lock while transaction updates are being calculated
Move transaction update helper class into separate file

Move logic to update Store into StoreTransactionUpdates

Fix a few issues / cleanup StoreTransactionUpdates

nodes.bodyText:
It's kind of terrifying for these to not be private - there's quite a bit of stuff that could be changing them. I do like having things split into separate classes though.
Maybe we should create a dedicated store package so that we have a very clear scope of what can access this stuff?  Maybe could even introduce a MutableStore interface that most things use (which extends ReadOnlyStore and adds the startTransaction methods).  Then the actual Store is only ever passed to the store helper classes.
Do these blocks wind up staying on disk? And is that an issue?

So to think through a conversation we've had offline about whether or not the call to storageUpdateChannel.onStorageUpdate needs to happen inside the write lock...

We can only have one thread importing blocks at a time, otherwise we'd mess up the in-memory state and various block validations wouldn't be accurate
There might be concurrent fork choice evaluations being done which would result in other store transactions interleaving, but those would only touch votes and blocks don't touch votes.

Thus, this is safe to do outside the write lock because no other block import can start until at least after this commit method returns, by which time the storage update has been sent and has the ordering fixed from there.
By releasing the write lock, even if storage is backed up read queries are able to be performed against the store which is good.
Currently block import waits for the returned future to complete before moving on to the next block and that will make this work, but if it didn't I believe we'd have an issue here because we aren't applying the changes to the in-memory store until the write to disk has completed.
The issue is that tx 1 makes the changes for block 10, then sends them off to storage, but at that point they haven't been applied to the underlying Store so are only visible to tx 1.  If the block importer didn't wait for commit to complete and moved on to block 11 - block 10 wouldn't yet be visible to it and it would fail.
But if we apply the additions before we know the storage works, we're a bit hosed if the storage fails because we then can't roll back.
So we probably need to stick with doing it this way and address it if we ever want to import blocks without waiting for storage (at which point we need to handle the error case anyway). We may want to just make commit() synchronous since everywhere that uses it does a .join() anyway.
It is really nice that this is in a separate class.

commit.message: Move Store to a dedicated package for better isolation
Put Store behind an interface, make Store package-private
